name: Antichamber
description: Antichamber is a mind-bending psychological exploration game where nothing can be taken for granted. Discover an Escher-like world where hallways wrap around upon each other, spaces reconfigure themselves, and accomplishing the impossible may just be the only way forward.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows XP SP2, Vista, or Windows 7 Processor:2.0+ GHz or better (dual core recommended) Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:NVIDIA 8000 series or higher (Shader Model 3 Compatible) DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:1 GB HD space

reviews.review_text: Someone once said 'If the laws of physics no longer apply in the future, God help you.'  That game is here.  God help me.

Pros: -If you love hardcore puzzle games this is the game for you. -Unlike other shallow games, this one tells a story, the Journey of life -as it was first called. You slowly see it unveil as you make progress. -The main feature that I like is that you never know what to expect in the next step you make. The map is full of surprises. -The design is beautiful and unique. -The game requires you to pay attention to details and think outside the box, then you will realize that the solution was right in front of your eyes. It has its own logic and its own specific style, and once you come in terms with it, you will love and appreciate every single puzzle.  Cons: -The music gave me headache after some hours into the game, so I had to turn the volume down. It's supposed to be soothing, but I personally found it a bit annoying. -There is no Antichamber 2

After playing for a bit, I can conclude that you will say these 2 things a lot:   1. Where the ♥♥♥♥ am I? 2. And how the ♥♥♥♥ did I get here?    In short   Antichamber is a puzzle game where the laws of physics and logic do not apply. Try and survive your way through the many, many ordeals in a world where common sense is non-existent. The game offers many philosophical messages which you will completely miss as you try to comprehend what to do and where to go. An amazing game if you want to lose your sense of logic and your sanity. Have Fun! 8/10
GOTY 2013!  Antichamber is amazing game that offers really hard puzzles and also meaningful notes about life in general. This game is an accomplishment since it was done by only 1 man.

'Mind-bending' is less a description of Antichamber and more a hint for solving its puzzles. The game clearly has its own consistent internal logic and random things don't just occur to mess with the player's head. However, many of Antichamber's puzzles depend on upsetting the usual order of things to - if the tablets of advice hidden around the game are to be believed - teach a lesson about life. It is not terribly uncommon, for example, to turn around and find yourself in a different place than where you came from. It makes no logical sense, but over time, it becomes a reasonable solution. While still sporting more straightforward puzzles like covering a series of sensors with a limited number of blocks, Antichamber seems to more often beg the player to look at the problem sideways. Instead of looking for tools to get around obstacles, understand that every situation may not operate under the same set of rules. Be willing to adjust assumptions based on new observations. But these observations need to be made independently by the player as the game itself provides no real external assistance; even the ultimate purpose of the game isn't handed to the player. Without guidance, you're left to discover your own meaning to the strange and sometimes inconsistent world around you - just as everyone must do as they progress through life.
It's not actually a puzzle game, it's a riddle game.

This isn't just a game. This is... is... is love! This is life!  It's hard to choose the words to describe it. Well, I would pick these: unique, original, remarkable, astounding, challenging, unearthly, intriguing, vivid, colors, headache.  For some people, it may be more appreciated along with an aspirin.  It may also cause deep thoughts, amazement and/or a slight frustration due to one's being too stupid to solve its puzzles. Beware.  I am immensely grateful to the developers for allowing this masterpiece to exist. Really,  thanks .

A mind-bending puzzle game that will leave you sucking ♥♥♥♥ to get more. I purchased this at the discounted rate of 5 smackaroos. Def worth it for that price I found myself getting stuck on puzzles and just leaving them like a smelly turd on the highway. Then I'd come back later and it would be a less smelly turd. A fun game. Check it out.
Great game. Way too many block puzzles in the later part of the game though.
Don't watch gameplay, Don't read detailed reviews, they will spoil you.  If you love puzzle games you'll love this.  Play it!
The game will make you....It will break you...and it will make you cry in a corner.
Mind-melting, preconception changing and really damn smart.

That´s particulary amazing. Even though I got this as a gift, I would have paid the full price. I should have got this way earlier, but I didn´t know if it was worth it. It is.   When you are playing this your first time you may be confused, you will wonder what kind of game this is. But if you are getting started, this becomes more and more interesting. Who said a game needs to look realistic? This is the proof that isn´t the case at all. Antichamber looks amazing, but yet UNREAL (got it?). You are wondering what that 'Antichamber' is, while you are trying to succeed. There isn´t much explanation needed, it´s easy to progress by trial and error and you still won´t get upset. I really enjoy the design, as weird as it is, and I always managed to play on. There are also a lot of hidden hints, all over the map, which is enourmous. Later you can even unlock some helpful abilities while you´re trying to find out what´s going on.   If you doubt like I did, don´t wait to buy it. If you like Puzzles, you will love this!
If you get confused easily, don't bother buying. This game makes no sense whatsoever, and then somehow makes even less sense after.
'None of your friends have played this game recently. Tell them why they should.'  Then I guess they aren't really my friends.. :P

Antichamber is a game in which I would describe a 'simulation' game. There are many types of simluation games, and this one does very well at simulating the process of being on drugs.  For the most part, Antichamber is a very simple game. You walk into walls to get guns so you can turn the black box man into an optical illusion. You can also click on pictures of bears and children that give hints along the way.  If you want a challenge of a game, this is the game for you as it tests your ability to stay sane while it spits weed out of your computer that you unintentionally smoke during the game. This likely explains why I feel different after playing an hour or two of this game.  All of the puzzles in this game are actually much more logical than they may seem, though you only find this out after you FINISH the puzzle and click on the hint duck pictures. Assuming you are NOT on drugs and can in fact read, I recommend you read the hints and take them into consideration. The signs never lie, just like people on the internet.  If I had to rate this game, I would probably give it a 400.20/420. There wasn't really a story at all, I guess is why that is. Otherwise I'd give it a full blazed 420/420. The art style is so simple yet fantastic, the puzzles are much more difficult than I was prepared for, and there were so many moments that I went 'OH that was SO satisying to finish!' though I may have been saying that about the weed that kept coming out of my computer. I HIGHly recommend this game.
Don't think I can recommend this highly enough. REALLY interesting mechanics in here, it blew my mind.

I bought it on sale, but even at full price it would have been worth it.  Firstly, you do not play Antichamber, Antichamber plays you.  If you had your sanity on the way in, chances are you lost it somewhere between the chirping bird corridors, the ending never-ending circle-spiral and the 23rd time you went down that same corridor by accident (except it wasn't that corridor, something's different this time). If you never had your sanity in the first place, you might regain some, this place probably makes perfect sense.  Buy this game if you like Legend Of Zelda dungeons, Portal maps or thinking. Don't buy it if you don't like fun, challenges or insanity.   Reality is an illusion! The world is a hologram! Buy gold!  Infinite cubes!  PS - Say hi to the purple cube for me.

10/10 would bang This game is extremely good For the first portion of the game I blazed through everything and was able to ace whatever was thrown at me Things quickly stopped and the game became mind boggling You never feel rushed and the environment is so soothing... I would strongly reccomend this game

You are nothing. A wanderer, adrift in a mysterious world that is otherwise physically impossible. Your memory is time and time, deceived. Deja vu moments and memory gaps, contradictorty as they may seem, plague your mind.  You obtain a cube gun, which generates... well... One can argue that you simply create cubes, and nothing else But one can also argue that you create life. The first cube gun, which can pick up and shoot little units, cells perhaps. Your tool shall evolve as you progress, as the quotes you encounter unfold a story of pictures.  You will create plant life, gardens of inward growth. Your gardens will transform into animals, primitive snakes of sorts, slithering upon command. You progress, a plague, a virus, horrendous, beautiful, but limited in dimension.  Your final form, a carrier, a harbringer of death, a black hole, a plague. The end of all, yet a beginning of a life of wisdom.  You play the story of one who creates life and death amidst a grand puzzle in which you attempt to define the impossible with what seems real to you. Only by performing the unconventional action within an unconventional space, rather than the conventional action within the unconventional space (which is not the same as performing a conventional or unconventional action in a conventional space) can you hope to progress.  Enjoy the game that teaches you more about life than society ever will.
Scroll up and click 'Buy' right now. You won't regret it.

I've seen people enjoying the competitive aspect of speedrunning it, but honestly, just keeping myself immersed in the game and moving on at my own pace over several hours was more than enough for me.  10/10

I recieved this game as a gift from one of my friends and even though I've only played about 16 minutes, it really is an astonishing masterpiece. I absolutely love the way this game directs the player because it really does force you (the player) to think differently. It isn't anything too impressive in terms of graphics but the optical illusions that have been designed in the game are just so....enigmatic. Another plus for me is that the game is littered with helpful quotes/hints and it is just something that isn't normally found in games these days. Final Verdict? Gambit Yes Uh! (it's an anagram)

To be honest, I feel the word 'game' berates antichamber. It's art in it's most purest form. It's about learning to think in non-linear paths, about approaching situations in different ways and memorizing and advancing in ways you're not used to. In more ways than one, this game is absolute madness, playing tricks with positioning that no sane mind would be able to memorize. However, in that process, it does offer a whole array of puzzles that make you feel good once you figure them out (okay...most of 'em. There are one or two really frustrating amongst them). The pictures and text feel better than all superfluous 'achievement unlocked''s combined.  The aesthetics may take some getting used to. It's all white, white and more white, but it grows on you. Coupled with the soft music, it really puts your mind at ease.  At first, I thought the whole game would be about brain puzzles. And while that was true, the block gun (and variants) do a good job of spicing things up without sacrificing neither the puzzle element nor the atmosphere.  I normally take the time to point out some the game's flaws, but in this case it would be a shame. Yes, some puzzles are frustrating, but is it because they ARE frustrating or because it requires the sort of thinking I personally am not accustomed to? It's probably the latter. And I really can't bring myself to criticizing the confusing structure of the whole, as it's that very structure that I come to adore. I mean...how many other games do you know where there's a 7-floor tower, complete with a sort-of-elevator shaft in the middle...where those seven floors are rooms that are located directly next to each other?  I just finished it for the second time (first time being a few years ago). As expected, I had sort of forgotten the harder puzzles, making it all the more challenging. And I'll probably replay it again in a few years from now. For puzzle games, that's a pretty unique feat. Take it for what it's worth. If there was a contest for best puzzle game ever, I'd not only nominate this, but criticise everyone who doesn't at least considers it.  In summary: best puzzle game ever. And I don't throw these nominations around lightly. ABSOLUTELY recommended.
Wait, where was I again?

In my life I've never played anything like this game before. My preconceptions were that this was going to be another portal clone - well that thought was shattered pretty quickly. It's more of a personal experience that focuses on how you approach Antichamber.  Puzzles are unique, different, and mindblowing. The only way i can describe when encountering them is the difference between veteren gamers and new gamers. Veteren gamers understand, and take for granted the logic and rules governed by most video games, while new gamers have to learn this process. For Antichamber, it abides by it's own rules - to the point that veteren gamers have to unlearn everything, while new gamers can learn the world without being hindered by pre-existing gamer knowledge. Unless you are a wizard that is!  The game progresses well, as you learn new concepts and apply them to other puzzles ... until the game pulls the rug under your feet like the slave you are. Here is an idea of what was going through my head for the majority of the puzzles. 'WHAT'?, 'Ok....', 'WHY AM I HERE', 'WHERE DO I GO', 'THIS GAME SENSE NONE'.  Stuck on a puzzle? No problem, move on to another and come back to it later. The intuitive map allows you to choose where to go next.   Aesthetics are simple with a uniquely distinctive art style. A white background with bright colours. The right contrast to entice you into the world, yet not distracting when taking in the environment to solve a puzzle. Accompanying the visuals is a soundtrack with various natural sounds.  The only negatives i can think of is if you don't like puzzles then this will be a frustrating experience. I had to take a break after solving several, although that comes with the genre more than anything.  I have been gaming for a long time and nothing has been quite as fresh and breathtaking of a experience than this game. My all time favourite.  10/10

I felt this game was amazing, and the best puzzle game i have played. I'm recomending it to everyone this is such a great game as well as it is very atmospherically heavy.I love everything about this game as well as it is VERY philosophical in a sense. In short this game is a ten out of ten.

I struggled on the recommendation page for ten minutes, trying to figure out how to sum this game up in a few bullet points. Here's my best go. -It's unique. -It's hard. -It requires you to doubt yourself constantly. -It requires patience. -The feeling of satisfaction achievable if you can remember the above four points is virtually unparalleled in any other game I've played in years.

I mean this in the best way possible: this game is just frustrating enough to not want to give up entirely at quite a few points.  I wound up 100%ing it oer the course of three days, and the way it is presented and developes the player is well thought out and well executed.  I don't want to comment on the difficulty or learning curve outside of 'it's doable'. If you keep going at it there is nothing you can't figure out, and the game makes it very easy to step away from a particular puzzle and come back to it. There is nothing in the game that can't be figured out with a little ingenuity or trial and error.   The art and animation are flawless and very pleasant to look at, and the little posters with phrases on them are a nice touch, even if the hints are a little late to be helpful at times(on purpose, I'm sure). Some of the puzzles are pretty clever and some involve a bit of synthesis.   Overall a really enjoyable experience. Well worth the purchase even at full price, 9/10.

Antichamber is a mind-bending game, with a very unique artstyle. It teaches you to look at things from many different angles. It's truly a game, which will make you think about stuff multiple times until you've found the answer. Going into it, I had a an idea of what it is going to be, since I've seen a first impression video about it, but even then some puzzles had me questioning my general understanding of things. Be warned, this is not your normal puzzle game like Portal or something, this is a complete different experience. I would recommend it to anyone, Puzzle and non-puzzle fans alike!

Antichamber. It's nothing like Portal, I don't know why people keep saying that. It's a first-person puzzle game with various clever elements that mix methodology with a labyrinth. Be prepared to face some really unique and puzzling scenarios. I've not seen any puzzle game like this, and for those who want a challenge and just all-around bizarre world, Antichamber is a great gem.
My brain hurts.

Antichamber, a game which hardly makes sense, except that sense is not required here, because all you have to really use is your brain, making your way through your 'life'. Basically this game is to teach some meanings of life, in a fun way, you have to make through various puzzles using tips used in real life, like for example: If you only think of right now, you won't have enough for later. Things that you mother and father would tell you during the course of your life. I can say that this game is not really supposed to have a story, I could say that this is mostly a game to think to solve the puzzles, and maybe learn something which is going to be REALLY useful in your life, in a fun way, until you are able to finish your 'quest' or as it can be seen in this game, your 'life'.  Graphics: I'll say that the graphic is quite simple, but yet very attractive and colorful (I love colorful games!) in some parts, and the block gun look very interesting and ironically, reverses the conditions colors I like to use specially in survival games (Blue for perfect health, Green for little damage, yellow for medium damage and red for heavy damage), being the first on the blue and the last the Red gun, as a little downside, I think most of the corridors were a little lifeless, the walls were all white, it gives you a strange feeling of lolyness, maybe it was the intention of the game (9.5/10) Story: Like mentioned before, I believe this game wasn't really made to have a story, except for learning some meanings of life in a fun way, and the player (which the appearance is unknown) must pass the challenges in his 'life', none of the happenings made any sense at all, like, why (s)he was there, who was (s)he, and what happened in the ending (I'll avoid making spoilers). The story didn't make much sense, so I'm afraid the story will get a so so rating, but hey! Just because the story is confusing somewhat doesn't mean the game is bad! (6/10) Sound: Whoa, how I did like the sounds in the game, the sounds gave quite a good touch to the game, when you are falling at a very high speed, that good sound of the air passing on your ears, when you land, and the sounds of you moving, absorbing and firing the blocks, gave a great touch to the game, in any moment I never got tired of the sound effects, and the music was very calm, a perfect music to let the player think through the puzzles, I simply have nothing but good things to say about the sounds (10/10) Depth: Depending on how well can you think on the solution of the puzzles, the game can take quite a while to beat (I almost beat the game 100% in around 20 hours, being some of those hours idle), and having various different paths, including some deadends, if you are looking to explore everything in the game, it's going to take a while, if you are just aiming to find the exit, the game will be a bit shorter, looking at the map (there is a map of the rooms explored on the wall of the game start chamber), the game seems to have needed to have a few more rooms. (8/10) Addictiveness: Awesome, I can safely say that until I could find almost all the black signs (you can see all the black signs you found during the game on the game start chamber), I never got tired of the game, but after I've given up to find the last 5 black signs, I didn't really feel like playing again. (8/10) Difficulty: I can say that the difficulty is at it's exact point to the human mind, the challenges fits exactly accordingly to a smart person, I had to put a lot of thought through the challenges, to solve 'em, some were simple, and some you had to be more experienced and have more 'Tools' to work them out. (7/10 = Tough)

Antichamber reminds me of LSD: Dream Emulator from PS1. If you enjoyed the Portal games, you'll love this just as much, if not more. It exercises both spatial and lateral thinking, and combines those with puzzles based on non-Euclidean geometry and artwork. It has a soothing ambient soundtrack and is all-in-all a fantastic gaming experience/journey; perhaps one of the best I've had in recent years. Definitely recommend this to anyone.

Antichamber is a very unique and really challenging game that made me feel most stupid and most clever at the same time. If you like puzzle games, this one has the best puzzles I've seen so far. You have to forget the laws of physics and video-games in general when going throgh Antichamber's non-Eucledian rooms. But if you do, you won't get confused but solve some rooms rather fast. However, lot of patience is required and you might even become stuck. In those cases I recommend returning to the game after a few days and trying again in a new way. (If you become desperate, drink a few beers and you will move on :D). To sum up, I really recommend this to anyone who likes to think and explore, the game is challenging and fun. Finished in 11 hours, I really feel clever :) 9/10

I don't think I've fallen in love with a game more instantaneously than I have with Antichamber. While I'm far from considering myself a 'classic gamer', one thing I find a bit exasperating about almost all modern games is how they will persistently hold your hand in a manner that, even if it doesn’t remove the challenge entirely, certainly does a lot to insult your intelligence. You will not run into this problem in Antichamber, and this for me is its main charm. Much like the very first Legend of Zelda game, AC starts you out in an unknown, unexplained world and you have to learn the rules by yourself, some writing on the walls telling you how to control your newfound matter gun (which I didn't even find until maybe 2 hours in playing the game and honestly completely forgot about until I did) and upgrades the only real guides you'll be getting, aside from some delightful life lessons you only receive after completing the puzzles they refer to. The simple puzzles quickly become daunting and brain-teasing, though a small few can become a bit tedious (and one puzzle in particular, albeit optional and only leading to an extra dev room, is complete and utter BS). However, for the most part the game has an excellent track record of keeping your mind stimulated and providing many rewarding and even cathartic moments, and many puzzles are an absolute joy for me to replay over and over again.  I also love the game’s minimalist presentation. You’ll be spending a lot of your time in pure white hallways, frequently visiting rooms that sport a color scheme ripped out of an MS Paint palette, but the game finds ways to use even its graphic simplicity to its advantage (many of the game’s puzzles and tricks wouldn’t work too well, I don’t think, in a more detailed aesthetic). I’ve seen people refer to the game as “ugly”, and while it certainly isn’t too easy on the eyes, it still finds ways to look just as charming as it plays.  At a glance, the game could easily be describled as 'Portal with blocks” (even though development on this game started a year before Portal was released), but what sets it apart from its mad scientist peer more than anything is while Portal follows a very linear storyline, AC is completely open, nonlinear, and ready and waiting to have every conceivable corner explored—as soon as you figure out your way around. Another important difference that makes AC stand on its own is that where Portal’s theme is based around physics, science and strict logic, AC’s theme is its complete and utter deconstruction of your preconceptions of logic and reality, and while logic isn’t necessarily completely absent from the game, it has created its own, new set of rules that, again, you have to figure out for yourself.  This game did have me stumped on more than a few occasions and I will admit have committed the sin of using a walkthrough to help me through a few of them (although all but one of them ended up being dev rooms), but after seeing the answers its clear that a player’s inability to proceed really does simply stem from their lack of ability to put pieces together rather than a negligence of giving you all the tools you need and teaching you how to use them—there are plenty of subtle, clever lessons leading up to larger problems, but it’s up to you to actually learn them and keep them in your head.  Overall, I’d say my only big complaint with Antichamber is that there isn’t more of it. There’s no real extra content aside from the hidden dev rooms, and apart from restarting your save file to finish with a faster time there isn’t exactly much in the way of replay value, and asking for a sequel to a game like this in my opinion would be outrageous. Still, if Bruce does come up with something, I’d love to see it and will be the first in line to get it. :) This game is without a doubt one of the finest I’ve played and is an absolute must-have for puzzle game enthusiasts.

I really enjoy puzzle games, but oftentimes, they're so inspired by each other that it becomes difficult to find one that really stands out and forces you to think around problems. That rare sort of innovation is what made Portal such a wonderful game, and the same goes for Antichamber. It takes some time to get used to wandering around Escher-like rooms, and by the time you think you've got the mechanics figured out, the game throws entirely new challenges at you.  The art style, both audio and visual, is a pleasant contrast to the challenging gameplay. Ambient rainfall or forest sounds accompany bright, contrasting colors, helping keep you calm and focused. Quite a nice choice for a game like this.  If you enjoy games that force you to exercise your reasoning skills, Antihamber is not a game to miss.

So, I just beat Antichamber. I think. The fact that I'm uncertain about that already tells you a whole lot about this game. In technical terms, one would describe it best as a first-person Metroidvania puzzler; but most conventional genre descriptors are far too generic for this convention-defier. If you love puzzles that are so headache-inducingly ingenious that the preposterous becomes intuitive, or if you just like to have your gray matter tickled, I'd definitely recommend this game.  One downside I'd note, though, is that - for some people, such as myself - the game is not only figuratively, but also literally headache-inducing. I'm not sure whether it's the brightness of the visuals, the ambient sound design, or what, but I found it difficult to play this game for extended stretches of time, which is a shame because the game is quite addicting!  Oh, I should also add, the game was very kindly gifted to me; I would not say it's worth its current price tag, though how long you'll be playing it will strongly depend on your wits and your willpower to resist looking up strategy guides.

Antichamber is a weird game to review, as it stands on a league of its own. It's not trying to be a good game. On the contrary, it's actually throwing most conventions out the window, and challenging the player to see it through.    Let's say it's a first person puzzle game. If you need a comparison, Portal would be a decent choice. However, where Portal clearly gives you the mechanics and expects you to use them to solve the puzzles, Antichamber makes you dig a lot to find those mechanics and how it all fits and interacts. The game is purposely trying to bend the players' minds at every turn, and it certainly succeeds in doing exactly that!   I'm not going to do the usual review on this game. It simply wouldn't work, and would achieve nothing. So I'm going to try to convey the game's fundamental aspects, and you'll then judge for yourself if you're interested enough.    The game also has some Metroid-vania elements regarding its map. However, while those games obey 'real-world' rules, Antichamber laughs at them. The whole game is a non-Euclidian maze (meaning it doesn't obey 3D geometry rules -- when you turn back, the rooms may have changed; maybe you can go down enough that you're back where you're started; you get the idea). However, you are given a very useful map, which functions almost as a progress meter. With its use, you'll know *some* of the connected areas, but above all else, you'll know when there are still ways to uncover in a given room.   Antichamber is essentially about sheer willpower and deconstruction. You're not given anything. Instead, you need to find it yourself, and then experiment with your new tools to solve more of the puzzles. The game also has a few signs with messages, giving you feedback for your actions (and the meaning of life, if you're so inclined). It works almost as  post-tutorialization . The game is about learning for yourself. About having to learn to progress. Since the knowledge you had previously (as conventions) doesn't work, you'll have to start from the very beginning. To solidify your discoveries, the game usually gives you a short phrase (and picture) to relate it to life itself. And it helps giving context to what you're doing, setting it all in stone.   Eventually, you'll be able to make the game's logic almost conventional, weirdly enough. You adapt to the weird world you've been thrown in, and it feels great to realize how far you've come.   There are lots of branching paths, each leading to a new puzzle. However, you have a Hub Area in which you can jump into every puzzle directly (after you've found it). It would be impossible to complete the game without it, since traversing the map is everything but convenient. This is also something that goes well with the fact that you'll be stuck a lot.  Either you haven't learned a certain mechanic well enough, or you're lacking a certain tool for a puzzle. But you'll be forced to turn back. And the game helps you with that a lot. So you'll be constantly trying out new puzzles, and shying away from others. It's fine. The game was made with that very intent, and it uses that to its advantage, avoiding a lot of frustration.    Another aspect is that there are mostly no wrong actions. Everything is a choice, and the game responds to everything you do -- it may just not be the answer you were looking for.  I've seen the question on the forums 'What's the point'? Well... there is not point, other than discovery, and basically deconstructing the world until you master its own way of thinking. You don't have anyone to save or kill. No reward waiting for you either. But curiosity will certaily keep you moving forward -- well, maybe not technically forward... up and to the right, maybe. Maybe backwards, who knows? -- and it's incredibly rewarding to solve some puzzles that were particularly difficult to you.     It is a very, very unique game. And it's hard to explain what it is or why anyone should play it. But I'll say this: it's the game I'd recommend to most people, even if they're not into games. And that's because it's an unique experience, not necessarily tied to traditional games. The same may happen with movies or even music. People may not like movies all that much, but there are some that are worth watching anyway, for one reason or another.   Again, it's on a league of its own. It also shares some similarities with Fez, in that regard. However, Fez requires you to take knowledge from outside of the game, while Antichamber requires you to throw all knowledge away.    There are also some Dev Rooms that will give you some information about the development of the game. It's nice that they're there.     If you want to be challenged, dazed and confused... Definitely get this game. And play it through without a guide, otherwise its charm is all lost. Persistence is important, but it's one of the most rewarding games I've played in a long, long time. And it works nicely as food for thought as well.   I have never played anything even remotely close to Antichamber (not saying it's the best game I've ever played, simply that it's very different from everything else I came across), and it's a well executed game. It's interesting not only in concept, but in practice as well. Give it a go!

First person puzzler with a high degree of novelty due to its 'impossible' physics.  Easily the most lateral thinking first person puzzler I have ever played. The overwhelming majority of problems have almost no vertical thinking component to them (there are a few mild exceptions to this), and this isn't at all a bad thing - this means that if you can't solve a particular puzzle, you are generally missing a foundational understanding of a particular concept. Oftentimes there are intermediate puzzles that you don't at all have to solve if you have learned a concept in order to be able to bypass them completely - but they are still there in order to be able to figure it out the first time.  I find the ambient soundtrack to be very effective and immersive.  The biggest negative for this game is that it's $20 for a 5-15 hour game. Its high level of novelty can justify that expense, but I'd suggest waiting for a sale.

Antichamber is a delightfully challenging first-person brain-tease. Calling it a puzzle game feels misleading, It doesn't merely *contain* puzzles; the entire game is the puzzle, and a viscous one at that.   After throwing you headlong into a bizarre and confusing environment to explore, the game gradually introduces you to new concepts and mechanics. However, it never shies away from introducing you to puzzles, gates, and dead-ends that you are not yet prepared or equipped to solve. Part of the game is learning how to overcome these obstacles. Another part is simply remembering where those obstacles are -- and how to return to them -- once you have the means to overcome them.  Antichamber is one of the most enjoyably maddening games ever. You will be stumped and confused. The game expects and wants you to be stumped and confused, and will do almost nothing to help you. It's not bad design, but rather the entire point and intent of the design. It's at once incredibly devious and incredibly rewarding.  I highly recommend it.

Similar to 'The Stanley Parable' this is a puzzle exploration game where all you basically do is try to find new paths to take that are different or unique to what you have previously completed.  The game itself is not all the 'fun' or 'exciting', but Antichamber does a good job of psychologically 'breaking the mould' that other games have put onto the player.  For example, when a game tells you to pick a path typically as a player you will choose one or the other. This game however likes to play mind games and will show you there is always another path. (back the way you came)  Then the game gets more complicated as you progress and turns into a 'Portal Like' game where you have a gun that can shoot blocks that you can use to hold doors open or block lasers to solve various puzzles.  As an experience this game is great, especially if you enjoy watching your friends fail seemingly obvious puzzles.  As a game...it's lacking on many levels.  - no story - no objectives / goals - no death / failure state - not much to do besides walk around, and sold various block puzzles to get to more puzzles - no replayability once you solve everything - puzzles get extremely complicated causing the user to just stop playing after a while  In short.... This is a game you experience once, and only once. It's a great experience, and you will love it at first, and want to show your friends, however... you won't want to ever play it again, and you'll likely just forget it even exists.  NOT worth $19.99  IS worth $1

I wasn't entirely sure which way to rate this one, but I think a thumbs-up is the fairer. Antichamber is fresh and different, challenging and thought-provoking, and offers a variety of inventive problems to solve, all presented in a unique but generally effective 'whiteout' style of visuals. Channelling the spirit of Portal into an artsier indie package, it's a welcome experience for adventure/puzzle fans. On the other hand, it's prone to induce as much frustration as fun, especially when the labyrinthine environments and abstract progression conditions cause you to start running in circles. When combined with the surreal imagery, this can make it feel like some kind of bizarre purgatory which your starving soul will never escape. But then, given some trial-and-error and perhaps the odd hint from the community pages, you'll break out of these loops soon enough. So if you enjoy this kind of game, it's worth a try.

What a treat! This game promised much and delivered way more than even that. Anyone who enjoyed the mind-bending properties of Portal will find this game takes that initial delight at the way games can bend physics and runs with it, resulting in gameplay that is an excellent balance of enjoyment and challenge.  In typical Indie fashion, there is no learning curve to speak of, leaving the player to scratch his or her head and re-examine the environment over and over again until the solution presents itself, yet there isn't any of the frustration associated with repeated failures.  There is no story line to speak of, although the ending gives tantalising hints of a larger world reminiscent of many sci-fi settings. Instead the player is presented with cutesy, collectable vignettes against the walls, accompanied by trite aphorisms playfully referencing the previous puzzle.  Despite its indie idiosyncracies I would highly recommend this game to anyone willing to mortgage a few very enjoyable days to it.

Quick Summary: Awesome Style Awesome Mechanics Interesting 'story' Lots of fun  Not sure how to describe it, but I'd say this is more of a brain teaser then puzzle game. One of the things that I liked about the level design is that the puzzles made sense. Without giving anything away, it felt like the levels all followed the same set of rules. There wasn't any infuriating puzzles that made you curse the developer, when you figured something out, it was like 'oh of course, that makes sense'. It really shows the developer's design skills when you can make an environmental puzzle challenging without resorting to stupid tricks.  The story: It leaves a lot open to interpretation, I don't want to ruin it, but there is something going on. It's creepy but not scary. Like you are waiting for something to jump out and attack you at some point. It keeps you on your toes and pushing you toward your ultimate goal.  I highly recommend this game, I have yet to play anything like it and doubt I ever will again.

Fun Fact: Antichamber, is not a word (To my Knowledge). The word that comes to mind is Antechamber; being a form of Entry-Room before a main or primary room, but not neccessarily a Hall or Mud-Room either. It is a more formal type of architectural structure. Antichamber is an extremely unique puzzle game. You utilize something that most people describe as a knock-off of the portal gun in a less graphically enhanced portal puzzle room.  This is entirlely incorrect. Antichamber presents the player with a beautiful and expertisely executed Escher-Esque enviornment, It also arms you with a gun that seems to have the ability to dissasociate matter from it's original state to compact transport and replace it in it's perfect atomically structured state upon which it was recieved. It does not by any means create inter-dimensional thresholds acting as gateways between time space and matter to transport a carrier through to different locations.  Check yourself.  Why are we in the antichamber? What is this ominous black snake that hovers through the air and disregards the puzzles we must solve? Who knows. This is left undiscerned for %100 of the game. Antichambers entertainment value is derived from Progressing through puzzles that break what we know as the laws of Space and Time. Physics can be completely disregarded, a shear wall can be dissasembled with the use of the Matter-Gun and moments later grow back from nothing to a brand new wall. An obvious empty space can be walked upon but if it is jumped towards it remains empty, the floor can dissappear because you looked at it, some doors only open when you don't look at them, trying to go back the room you just came from can often become impossible because you rounded the corner.  The game is EXTREMELY unique, and difficult at times. It has points of Trial-and-Error but keeps those entertaining as well, as compared to most puzzle games creating a sense of droll repetativeness from them. No Story, but superb mechanics, awe inspiring enviornments, this is a game that I believe was made to take a step forward in what we can consider puzzle-based gameplay, it transcends normal puzzles, there is never a point of stopping and solving a tile-puzzle or the like. You progress to get four different guns with four different functions and the game makes you to use all the the things you learned to solve the final few puzzles in a dramatic and slightly adrenaline inducing chase-sequences.  If Antichamber isn't on your wishlist, you'd better own it.

Words cannot describe the sheer mind blow this game causes... so here I go, using words to describe it!  Everyone makes a lot of connections to Portal, and it's easy to see why: Both games use a special gun to interact with their respective game worlds, both games use white... a lot, and they both focus on puzzles (obvious statement is obvious). However, if one compares the progress you make in each game, Portal is definately the more linear game, while Antichamber is... DEFINATELY NOT linear. Antichamber will make you go forwards, backwards, side to side, through walls, chutes, and interconnected chambers, and all you have to help you are the many signs posted throughout the game, your matter gun [once you get it, of course], and your brains.  One issue is the control scheme, which is more or less locked; You move throughout the game using six keys off the keyboard, and your mouse manipulates the matter gun (shocking!). However, with regards to the mattergun, when you need to use the wheel button on your mouse, and your mouse either lacks one, or it doesn't respond when you press it in game, use the left ctrl key to make up for it; not informing the players that the left Ctrl is a viable button did put a damper on my own experience playing the game.  While Antichamber does not have any achievements at the time of this review, it can be easily said that if you play through Antichamber for the first time, I GUARANTEE you will say 'What the #$%^' at least a once... if you aren't just saying it through the entire game.

Antichamber is a puzzle game that focuses on typical gaming conventions, such as basic 3D space, and then utterly breaking them. It is a game for Escher fans, a game of exploration and unlearning and relearning rules.  If you feel like you want to enter and explore a realm that has no basic laws of physics, or a game that is stunning to discover and entices you to explore it, or even just a game that forces you to change conventions and take a hard look at how and why certain, VERY logical things are designed, then you my friend have very perculiar tastes. Also, this game is for you.  I wouldn't say this is worth $20 or $15 dollars, tho. I would say it's more of a $10 game. Plus, I have run into some issues that crashes the game (really late game, tho). So you might want to hold off until a sale.

Is Portal 2 too easy for you? Do you scoff at the computer while playing Scribblenauts? Do you want something more, something that redefines 'Puzzle' while combining 'Indie' at the same time?   Then Antichamber is the game for you.  Imagine a puzzle game in a wacky universe where things generally does not make sense. Imagine a puzzle game where your only friend are curious signboards plastered around the hallways. Imagine a puzzle game where you turn around and suddenly, the halls have changed behind you. Imagine a puzzle game where the floor opens up and you fall for eons and eons just because you followed a suspicious arrow.  In this extremely colourful world of Antichamber, you find yourself thrown into a set of chambers and puzzles with absolutely no idea what is going on. All you have is your wits and an anti-matter gun. ... Oh wait, you don't have that yet. You got to find it first.  With the clock ticking down, you will start to feel the rush and the pressure to find your way out, sometimes only through persistence and raw tenacity. Your brain gets really worked as you try to fathom this non-Euclidean world, where all you know does not make sense.  Or perhaps this game is trying to remove the 'contemporary mindset' that many puzzle games out there advocate.  As a caution, do not attempt to find video walkthroughs on this game. It will severly dampen the experience and you would have essentially wasted your USD20 if you watch someone else play the game.  Get it now while it is on sale! 8/10

If you want a good experience, go ahead and buy this game. It mind♥♥♥♥s you so hard at times and the puzzles are actually very clever. Keep in mind this isn't really a game you play to have fun, it is an experience and one of the best experiences I have played, definitely not for everyone. If you are prone to headaches, you may not want to buy this game, a friend of mine gets a major headache whenever he plays the game for more than 15 minutes.

As a puzzle game, it's trumped by Portal's cool factor, or Braid's art style, or what have you, but on the basis of puzzles themselves, this has them beat for a mixture of elegance and satisfying difficulty.   As a visual experience, this game's experimentation with space and perspective is seamless. The game constantly warps the space you're in, but I never feel like I see 'behind the curtain,' when or how it's being done.  As a narrative commentary on game design, this game is what I wished The Stanley Parable was. Everything The Stanley Parable  tells  you, Antichamber  shows  you. You actually  play  the philosophy, rather than going on a walk through a Source engine museum with a funny but empty commentary track.  Addendum: I thought for a bit about why The Stanley Parable was unsatisfying but Antichamber was satisfying. I think The Stanley Parable made too many assumptions about my behavior that weren't true; I thought I'd have choices I didn't. I couldn't pick up a coffee mug, or open the doors I wanted to open, or go any direction instead of one of two or three predictable hallways. I felt like it thought I was stupid, and every decision point felt contrived. Antichamber (and I realize this is subjective) somehow was always one step ahead of me. It accounted for every decision I made. I realize it's a less detailed world, so there's less possible decisions, I suppose, but it still has the effect of feeling genuine. The Stanley Parable was a set piece, Antichamber was an experience.

At first glance, Antichamber seems kind of daunting. A game that breaks rules and bends the world around you? Sounds messy, confusing, and full of trial-and-error. Happily, that's not really the case. Though it enjoys playing around with unconventional and unexpected level design, there's nothing particularly strange or out there about this game. It's just a solid, well-paced, enjoyable puzzle game that'll probably run you 5-9 hours depending on how much of a completionist you are.   There are a few hiccups along the way: a couple of minor technical issues disrupt the immersion a little bit, but the game's not broken by any means. Once or twice, a puzzle took me 10x as long as it should have just because a simple mechanic was never really explained, but again, that never ruined the experience. The atmosphere hints at some sort of minimalist story, but in the end there's no actual narrative—not that there needs to be one.  Those downsides are strongly outweighed by the good parts. The unique visual style looks much better in motion than it does in screenshots. The game's mindbending navigational chaos is counterbalanced by puzzles that you can't fail (or, at the least, that you can easily reset) and a world map that turns out to be extremely helpful for getting around. Furthermore, once the game does introduce a rule, it's consistent; once you learn something about the world, you can rely on that knowledge for the rest of your playthrough.  The end result is a highly satisfying and easily recommendable puzzle experience. If you're vaguely in the mood for this kind of thing, don't hesitate in picking it up.

I bought 'Antichamber' out of sheer curiosity. I was entertained by the variety and uniqueness of puzzles that are not found in many AAA games that I play, the general creativity of the game, the minimalistic art design, and the paltry directions or clues for most puzzles. However, 'Antichamber' felt like a barrage of puzzles, with barely any moment for players to soak in the moments -- similar to trying to get out an escape room before the timer runs out.  While I do recommend 'Antichamber', I cannot say I am highly entertained by it. If you enjoy solving puzzles for the sake of solving puzzles, I think this game is for you. I personally prefer games that give me a purpose to solve the puzzles and a clear end goal; 'Antichamber', in this regard, felt like an escape room game in which you have no idea why you want to escape and what you're escaping from.

I wouldn't say this is the best puzzle game, or the most engaging, or interesting, but it's definitely a memorable and unique experience. I love the concept of solving puzzles by figuring out the laws of the always changing realities within this game. But sometimes the puzzles are a bit phoned-in and feel out of place. When a good deal of the puzzles make you go 'a ha!' and then some are puzzles you've seen before - which makes them extra disappointing, if you stack them up to the mind bending ones.  The progression in this game isn't smooth at all. Maybe it's not meant to be. But I will say that your first hour of this game vs the rest of this game, are entirely different experiences. a joyful, steady progression, turns into a series of 'wtf''s that result in a deeply satisfying feeling for having progressed. It's like sprinting then being forced to take baby steps. Keep in mind, that's my personal experience with it. and the thing with puzzle games is that progression is partially based on the players ability to solve the puzzles. But the more the antichamber opens up, the more I started dabbling in rooms here and there, figuring out where I should be going next.   Very often, because of this, I'd be stuck on a puzzle, only to notice that a few rooms back (in a different direction than where I came from) there was a hint on how to solve it.... if only I had come through the 'correct' route. But there is no correct route. Which made me learn that backtracking and approaching a room from another direction is far more beneficial than just.... trying to solve the puzzle. I just plain don't like that.  Having said all that, I am enjoying this game a great deal. And will be pretty sad if/when I ever complete it. Because this game definitely has zero replay value (unless you arbitrarily want to complete it as fast as possible) as 90% of it's charm comes from initial impressions

A puzzle game where playtime varies wildly considering you don't have to complete every single puzzle to get to the end. I beat it in about 2 hours so either I'm a supreme genius or this game has different ways to complete it; it's most likely the latter as you can beat this game in two minutes if you know what to do.

Generally, games of this style don't have much replayability. You explore, you solve puzzles, you reach the ending, and aside from a few Easter eggs hidden around, there isn't much new to do on later runs, and repeating the same puzzles over and over takes away the charm.  I should let you know that my first playthrough of this game was ~2 hours of my displayed playtime. On top of that, I've played this game when I haven't had Wi-Fi access, so this is only some of my time playing this game.  This game can best be summarized by a quote from the legendary band Smashmouth, 'So much to do, so much to see, so what's wrong with taking the backstreet? You'll never know if you don't go.'  You can go, start to finish, through this game in less than 10 minutes. You can also, without lingering or backtracking too much, spend hours on a single playthrough. And literally nothing changes in the maze. But the order you find things in - things you didn't know before but know now, assumptions you make one time that you test a different way another time - will likely change (unless you're a speedrunner, of course).  This is a game I recommend to anyone who enjoys lateral thinking puzzles, puzzles in general, exploration, and the works of Mondrian, Doesburg, Escher, and Dali.  Overall, I'd say this is one of the best games I've ever played, but using an arbitrary number to grade it wouldn't give it justice. If you need a tl;dr number out of 10, though, I'd say it's a 9/10. It doesn't really have a memorable soundscape, but it doesn't need one, as it's less of a cinematic experience and more of an ambient journey.

Walls with eyes on them that fail at staring contests.   That is Antichamber…

The game does a bit of a sin by sort of misleading you about what the game is about, but it's still very good.  At it's heart, Antichamber is a block puzzle game, in which the rules of the room and puzzle change and evolve over the course of the game. At it's best, Antichamber forces you to think in non-euclidian ways in order to solve a puzzle, and it does this often. However, it can also leve you google searching the answer to the puzzle, because the actual answer is so obtuse it seems ridiculous.   Overall, if the trailer caught your eye, and you're in it for just that, you'll be dissapointed. If you want a good puzzle game though, it's still a great game to pick up.

Antichamber is a puzzle platformer set in a mysterious non-Euclidean testing ground where the rules of geometric logic and dimension do not apply. Mazes and hallways with impossible infinite loops, whole areas contained in deceptively small spaces and portals that allow you move you from room to room simply by changing your perspective are all common place here. The addition of a Matter gun that lets you manipulate special material, various traps, secrets and testing apparatuses make for a complex and often confounding experience. At the same time, the game's unique sense of pacing keeps it from ever getting too frustrating. You can't die - instead if you get stuck you're able to instantly warp back to the main hub at any time. The main hub acts as a map where you can revisit any room you've discovered thus far, so you're able to tackle whatever area you want when you're ready to solve it and you're very rarely forced to do any excessive backtracking. There is a timer, but (without spoiling what happens if it runs out) there isn't much sense of urgency. Along with a rather pleasant ambient soundtrack that slowly builds as you progress, Antichamber is a unique experience that can prove to be just as serene as it is mindbending. Highly recommended.

Yes, it's a puzzle game, but the puzzles aren't restricted to the game - Antichamber actively challenges the basic logic you would normally try to apply. In many games, this feels unintuitive and comes off as an insult... But Antichamber politely pushes you into the right path with a calm indication that 'no, there's a bit more to it than that.'

This game is one of my top game of all time. Simple as that. I don't want to give away any thing at all so I'll keep it simple. This puzzle game is mind boggling and fun. This game challenges you to think not only outside the box but the chamber that the box is in. There is no direct story but this game pushes the progression through a series of puzzles to lead you to an end. I didn't get as much satisfaction as I expected when I reached the end but the journey there was memorable and you can't complete the game without exploring every puzzle it has to offer. There are some hidden developer rooms that can be explorered. These rooms provide insight into the making of the game via gun concepts, code diagrams, etc... There are also some purple blocks that are peppered around the map which don't have any impact to the games progression and has no real worth. The puzzles are really good and there was a few occasions where I had to look online for answers. I eventually found myself solving some of the puzzles faster than tutorial videos on youtube. Some puzzles have different ways to solve them.   There is currently a Humble Bundle that includes this game and I would definetely recommend getting it. Even if it isn't discounted, it is still worth experiencing.   If you love puzzle games, non-Euclidean geometries and getting your mind blown then don't pass Antichamber up.

Antichamber is an outstanding puzzle-game.  It breaks conventional rules and it doesnt take long until some new established rules will be broken by the player. The game attacks many assumptions you might have had without knowing you had them,  or at the very least reminding you that they're there  Playing the game also shows how easy it is to fool you until you adjust to the new world. Which is why I consider it also to be a game about games. It proves that without a Plot and just very simple mechanics  a game can still be insanely addictive, immersive and yea - just amazing. Solving puzzles feels very rewarding, but I would argue that this isn't even Antichamber's biggest strenght. It's experiencing yourself as you play.   10/10

An easy to use 'fast-travel' system also lets you jump around and tackle other sections of the game if you ever get stuck. I absolutely LOVED this game! After days turned into months which turned practically into a year of trying to figure out the last and final piece of the puzzle, I WAS THRILLED to one day just know how to do it. I tried and tried for so long to figure it out and I DID IT! I was so happy! My brother who also played this game had to look up walk-throughs, but I did it without any help and I couldn't tell you just how happy and accomplished I feel.  There are one or two puzzles I left unsolved, so I'm going to go back and make sure all the large squares become small! Loved everything about this game. The tricksy switches, the mind blowing end game puzzle that was much simpler than it seemed, the amazing and relaxing music that really helps you unwind after a hard, long day. Literally every single thing about this game. I liked it just as much as I enjoyed the Portal series! I also LOVED the little signs after each puzzle that would teach you or help explain something, that all leads up to the bigger picture. It's just so phenomenal. I wish I could give it more than 10 stars because it was that great... Again, I'm a huge puzzle game player though... THey ruin the game and overall accomplishment when you finish :) Was so impressed. Definitely recommend.

A very cool, mind bending puzzle game. Has some definite similarities to games like Portal and Quantum Conundrum, but there's enough different to stand off on its own. You'll find it turning your brain inside out at how often you can literally turn around and find something different in front of you. Many of the puzzle rooms seem outright impossible at the start of the game. As you progress further and further, the solutions generally become obvious as you gradually learn more advanced methods to solve the puzzles (these methods usually come along at the same time as an upgrade to your cube gun). The controls for moving the blocks from one spot to another can be a tad aggrivating when you're trying to move them around in 3D space rather than just inside the 2D puzzle sections. That doesn't really detract at all from the overall game though. Highly recommended if you are into games like Portal. 9/10

Antichamber is for the individual who wants their mind blown. While technically a first-person puzzle game (portal, not tetris), the rules of antichamber are not as concrete as in most puzzle games. Without spoiling anything about this compelling experience, I will iterate that this game's style of puzzles are not something I've seen accomplished in a video game. Most 'puzzles' in this game are not traditional logic puzzles found predominantly in Portal, nor do they require the same cryptic detective work necessary for the Myst series. Instead what we have here are more like spacial brainteasers manifested into a 3d exploration game. The world plays around with what we expect to happen in a normal 3D environment, but it does not stick to the now popular perspective swap trickery like echochrome or fez. Every corner you turn you must learn something new about the world you exist in, and almost none of that applies to the next room. It somehow does this without ever contridicting itself. This is not a game for the man looking for a set of logic puzzles like soduko, which increase in difficulty but with static mechanics. It also does not contain any real narrative, instead preffering the abstract over explicit. But having a traditional story or characters would dilute the potent head trip offered up here.

Really well-executed, mind-bending puzzler. If you loved Portal but wished for more variety+difficulty in the mechanics and even less of a traditional narrative, then Antichamber is for you! :-)  The puzzles were challenging, engrossing, lateral-thought-provoking ... but still mostly 'fair,' if that makes sense. I admit to getting hints online 3-4 times on the way to beating the game, and in most of those cases after seeing the solution I said 'glad I checked; I wouldn't have noticed that in a million years.' But I weigh that against the 30-40 puzzles I solved that were 'just right' in terms of novelty and difficulty, and the game is a clear winner.  If you like first-person puzzle games, this is well worth your $15 and the 7-8 hours that an honest play-through will take.

This has been the most interesting gaming experience I've had for a while, mixing exploration with puzzle solving perfectly in the midst of an eerily tranquil atmosphere. The difficulty is pitched perfectly with challenges that feel rewarding to solve, with hints that are cryptic, but not so obscure that they aren't unhelpful. I found most puzzles that seemed 'unsolvable' were resolved after stepping back and returning later with a new approach. Remembering what you have learnt before, but finding new ways to approach things is key here. It's a fantastic experience to encourage you to look at anything from a new perspective and genuinely feels rewarding to find a solution.   Definitely not for the impatient, but certainly a great experience for those who like exploration and challenging puzzles.

I don't think I can avoid comparing this game to Portal: the whole game revolves around overcoming an environment of obstacles using a novel and creative means of interacting with that environment, solving a variety of puzzles using the player's gradually increasing set of capabilities. However, this game succeeds where many others of its kind fail: experimenting with and discovering new ways to exercise the player's capabilities feels satisfying, and the game's many challenges feel novel and varied in the puzzle-solving strategies they require, in an environment with just enough artistic touches to stay visually engaging despite the overall visual minimalism.

Antichamber, this is really quite hard to review, but I am going to anyway and I'll try my hardest not to spoil anything like the big final boss part where the protagonist finds out that his father is actually the antagonist! Oh ♥♥♥♥! The reason this is hard to review is because this is less of a game, more of a tool for making you hate everything ever. It is really confusing and seems to have started a career as a TOTAL ♥♥♥♥ because everytime you think you have the solution to a puzzle more complicated than the theory of ♥♥♥♥ing relativity you find out that all you had to do is turn around or jump or some ♥♥♥♥ like that! Ok, ok. I'll go over everything like a proper review.   The game mechanics are where the main focus is in this title and the 'fun' with quotes so large they could be mistaken for the side of Mozambique is the fact that there aren't really any game mechanics besides 'nothing is as it seems.' I see they have gone to the Assassin's Creed school for cynical as ♥♥♥♥ philosophy. This game isn't really fun, but its not supposed to be. It's supposed to kick your brain to the curb and ♥♥♥♥ upon it and it succeeds in that.   Graphics, or lack thereof. The graphics are the most overatted bit of gaming. I've seen great games be panned because you can't see the coffee stain on the main character's left armpit or can't see each vein individually as the main character lumbers his or her power suited self into the field of generic cover based tripe. The truth is that graphics are less important than a politicians promise and if they were a person they'd be like Dane Cook or something. This game has very little in the way of looks and that is fine. This game doesn't need to be fancy looking to ♥♥♥♥ with your head. My only problem with the aesthetic is that it seems empty. Portal used a similar, if not slightly more detailed method of sterile white environments, but the thing is that it worked better in Portal because you have characters that speak and are funny and such. Antichamber seems lost without something like that or a real goal.   Until, I found the end door, which is in the starting room and I didn't notice. I thought to myself, has this game been just a huge troll to lead me back here and inevitable notice that I had been staring at the End the whole time... No, there is a cheekily placed peice of glass in the way and about 20 minutes later when I found a way behind the glass the door was unopenable. Well played, Antichamber, well played.   Now, here's the part where I recommend it or not. The game is great for a certain type of people. These are the patient types that enjoy being outsmarted by a piece of software. I am kind-of in this group, and I kind of liked it. It is not good for the twitching xbox gamer who can't go more than a femtosecond without teabagging (in a game, it would be incredibly humorous elsewhere) or killing someone. So if you enjoy energy drinks named after some predator's urine, don't play it.

The puzzles, want to make 6 right turns to go left?   How about walking through solid walls backwards?  WHAT about a game of Britsh Bulldog with a load of floating balls?  All this and more awaits you in Antichamber. It looks at spacial awareness and says 'bugger that' and does its own thing.   The puzzles are fendish at times, but new tools and skills along the way get you by. Took me 5 hours to complete, as I plot. I seen speed runs of 30mins.  I enjoyed it, no real story but its a very diffrent sort of game.

A stunning puzzle game that really bends your mind around for a few hours as you struggle to accept its logic. To succeed, you have to force yourself to forgot how the real world works, forget how places are arranged in space, and really think out of the box. The first couple of hours are pure mind-bendy bliss! The second half of the game gives you a bit more of a traditional puzzle experience in the vein of Portal. It has you using a gun that removes or deposits blocks in various ways to affect switches, build bridges, and move yourself around. This second part is markedly less awe inspiring after the first half, but its still a very fun and competant puzzle game.   Big shout out to the subtle and ambient audio in the game. It does so much to enhance the feeling of mysterious wonder that fills the entire complex.   Probably the best puzzle game I've ever played and a fantastic experience.

This game is a real challenge! It goes to show that you can have very minimalistic, intuitive game play without lengthy tutorials that distract from the overall experience.  So, if you're solely a graphics-loving FPS kinda guy, you probably would want to stay away as this is an artsy puzzler. If you love puzzles and like a steadily growing difficulty level, this is definitely for you.  In Antichamber, you start out with basically yourself and a goal to 'finish the game' -- whatever that means. Slowly, you will come to understand the puzzling world around you and how and why certain things work the way they do. At some point, you will find a gun that helps you in various spots on your way. Even as you accumulate more and more powers, the game never gets old, always keeps you on your toes.  The ending is also very promising, so you won't find yourself accidentally finishing the game and then ask 'That's it?!' It's a rewarding experience that requires lots of lateral thinking and a skilled mind to complete and is well worth the effort of navigating this truly unique game.
Really interesting game, if you can get it on offer, I'd recommend it.

HEALTH AND SAFETY WARNING: Do NOT play Antichamber if you are prone to severe headaches and/or migranes, because Antichamber does just that. The game is specifically designed to get you out of your comfort zone. While not aesthetically appealing, it doesn't need to be visually stunning to stun you. While it has traditional puzzles, like jumping on platforms that sink under your weight to make you go higher, to more obscure puzzles, like going through a door backwards because every time you look at the door it closes. Here is an example **SPOILER ALERT**  You approach two staircases, one going up and one going down. If you chose the up staircase, it returns you to the staircase. If you chose the down staircase, the same thing happens, but if you go back the way you came there's a new path.  These kinds of puzzles gave me headahces on end, and had to stop playing the games. Later on you get a type of gun that shoots blocks. You use these block to open doors, solve puzzles, and if you run through certain areas you lose any blocks you're carrying (emancipation grid anyone?) Anyway, Antichamber will change how you problem solve and go about doing things differently, the apex of psychological puzzles. Sometimes you'll find pictures on the walls. These pictures can be toggled to show a sentence or two, teaching valuable life lessons. I like that much, and have made many friends following those lines.  Pros: Interesting gameplay life lessons abstract puzzles  Cons: Can give certain people migranes confusing puzzles  Verdict: 7/10 Antichamber i would highly recommend if you like abnormal puzzle, but this is nothing like the momentum based puzzles of Portal. You could sit in a room for an hour and not figure out the puzzle. If you like to take a trip that tests you sanity, then Antichamber might be a good buy.
A very rewarding, fun and creative puzzle game. Well worth playing.

This was a pleasant surprise. It's a FPS Puzzle/Platformer with minimalistic graphics, but that doesn't mean it's not a 'pretty game'. The lack of details help it accomplish some of the dimension-bending puzzles that make Antichamber such a trippy experience. The best comparison I can think of is Portal, but only in game mechanics. Otherwise the games are complete opposites, and yet both still work beautifully.  Portal = Fleshed out story; Antichamber = No story provided at all (you make your own guesses on what's going on) Portal = Humorous characters and script; Antichamber = No talking or other characters (you are completely alone) Portal = The game provides direction on where to go or what to do; Antichamber = You get no help. Explore and figure it out yourself. Both games = You get a nifty 'gun' to help you  Like Portal, Antichamber ends up being a fairly short game (the gameplay is mainly from exploration and trying to figure out what to do), but if you enjoyed Portal and can get Antichamber for a good deal, then I definitely recommend picking it up.

A puzzler for the Portal crowd, Antichamber will certainly take your head and spin it around. Prepare to think in totally crazy ways as you explore a mysterious puzzle compound searching for hidden wisdoms and a way to get to the mysterious door labeled only 'The End'. It's actually a pretty good length for a puzzler, and the dropping of any pretense of a story works in it's favor as it cuts the distance between you and the gameplay. However, this is also my biggest issue with it: because there isn't a story and we're simply working towards an ending, there really isn't anything substanial to gain from playing it. The puzzles only serve to proceed you closer to finishing the game and acquiring new wisdoms, which aren't really wonderful just by the fact they are, in total, generic and plentiful. So, to wrap up, a good puzzler lacking anything to take away from it basically sums up Antichamber.

Antichamber is a FPS puzzle game that I will call the thinking man's Portal. You are dropped into the game world and allowed to figure out the rules of the various types of puzzles and given a reasonable amount of freedom to determine your own solution. This game is an example of a non-linear puzzle game that allows lateral thinking in solving its puzzles.  Also, while there isn't really a story, the game will give you 'rewards' in the form of pictorials at the end of each puzzle you complete. One thing I really liked is that all of these pictorials had positive, thoughtful messages. So not only is Antichamber a thoughtful challenging game, you feel happier as you play!  My only complaint was that it was too short.

Anti-Chamber is a game hard to discuss with someone unless they have played through it, making it challenging to review without ruining certain aspects. The game is developed by a single indie developer from Australia named Alexander Bruce and this is his first formal released game. AntiChamber is a bizarre experience that not only challenges the way you think but pits traditional thinking patterns against you, where walls may not exist depending on how you look at them, and stairs can bring you to the same place no matter which direction you take. AntiChamber will keep you questioning yourself the whole way through. Although it is purely single-player, AntiChamber does not have a conventional story; the game is what you make of it. The hints for puzzles double as philosophical messages as you continue to navigate through the strange halls of the cold sterile environment.   When you launch the game you are immediately thrown into the world of Anti-Chamber, where conventional video game logic is made useless. There is no “Main Menu”; instead the box that you start in serves as your menu. You can change the resolution and mouse sensitivity by looking at and clicking the various buttons, but this box also serves as your main hub for the rest of the game. From this hub you are able to instantly teleport to any puzzle that you have encountered so far, and because Anti-Chamber is a very non-linear experience you will be free to go to any place you want, and if you have the wit you can even complete some puzzles without the necessary tools.   There are a variety of different puzzles in Anti-Chamber but the majority of them require the use of a matter manipulating gun. Initially the gun allows you to pick up blocks and place them down but as you progress you will be able to upgrade to manipulate the blocks in different ways to help solve more complex puzzles. Throughout the game there are vague illustrations with text on the walls that act as hints and as you view them the picture gets saved in the main hub for your viewing later. Early on in the game I found it difficult to distinguish which puzzles I was actually capable of solving but as the game hinted “failure to succeed does not mean failure to progress”. If there is a puzzle that you have no idea how to do, it is best to just leave it and try a different one as the other puzzles may teach you new tricks.   The world of Antichamber looks simple and phenomenal at the same time which compliments the game from both an aesthetic point of view and also a design approach, as it helps when faced with the most difficult puzzles to understand the environment. From the sterile white to the vibrant green, blue and red, the game has an artistic style that is simple yet very effective. It is a welcomed departure from games that give you a visual overload like Crysis 3. This is not to say that Antichamber is a bad looking game; the colours and interesting environments gave me more “Wow!” moments than other big titles such as Crysis or Battlefield. However, it could use a little anti-aliasing to smooth out the edges. Even though it’s using Unreal Engine 3, the game is not very demanding performance wise. The only downside is that you can’t tinker with the options menu and are forced to use the WASD control scheme (but if you want you can change this in the config files).  The music and sounds of Antichamber compliment its vibrant, sterile atmosphere with chilling calm tones. It has quite the relaxing effect as you wander the halls trying to solve different puzzles. The music is done by Siddhartha Barnhoorn and has an interesting and unique sound that really sets the tone of the game. Here is a brief sample of some of the music from Antichamber.          YouTube™ Video:  Antichamber OST - Antichamber Suite I
