It might sound weird to call a game 'important,' but Antichamber really pushes the envelope in terms of how a game can change the way you think - both about games and about yourself. Every time I think I've mastered an element of gameplay, I turn a corner and go *right* back to feeling like a rat in a maze. The greatest moments are when I am forced to deliberately drop what I think I know, start from scratch, and see everything with new eyes.  If you think of games as art, then this is a masterpiece of minimalism, speaking volumes with a paucity of elements. If you don't think of games as art, then this will change your mind about that. If you think games can't be art, then just play this anyway and see what you think.

Ow... my head...  Do not mistake this game for a Portal remake. It's less about learning the rules and how to apply them... but more about discovering how the creators can well and truly bend the rules to screw with you. In fact, where Portal sometimes suffered with 'puzzles' coming down to how quickly you could react / move - 99% of Anti-Chamber comes down to purely trying to out-think it. The puzzles are divine and the steady inclusion of increasingly-versatile matter guns keep the challenges and dynamics fresh  For the most part, the balance is struck just right: That frustrating mind-ache as you get completely stumped, followed by that invigorating moment when you finally crack it. There's no tutorial, which creates a nice quirk where you're forced to explore, look around and touch things - doing God-knows-what to try to make sense of what is and isn't possible. You can't help but smile weakly as it feels like the puzzles are mocking you in the background... revenge for all those times you laughed as your less-gamer siblings tried to play your games and hopelessly failed. It's surreal but so enjoyable  There's no 'plot' per se... but you are guided around by some very simple, yet beautiful, chalk drawings. They're charming, sometimes quite funny and really add a warm touch to an otherwise sterile environment  Who needs cake...
Comparing this game to Portal is futile. Yes, both give you a gun-like device. But in the mind-bending puzzle department, Antichamber gives you so much more. And those graphics are gorgeous.

This game is bizarre and fascinating. It took me 8 hours, largely from exploration and dinking around, to complete all but one of the available 'room tiles' (I'm not going to look through walkthroughs to figure out which one I missed) as well as complete the minimal story.  The game plays with your mind a lot in the beginning, but eventually you become accustomed to what it is doing. As I played, I looked at everything from a programmer's perspective, thinking about how each alternate view, turn around shift, and whatnot had to be coded for. It was almost as intriguing to me to try to think about how I would code these things as it was figuring out the puzzles in the game. This is the first... ~1/4 to 1/3 of the game, and it was fascinating. If the entire game was 8 hours of this sort of trickery, I would have rated this as one of my absolute favorite games. It's still a great game, but...  ... things changed once I got the first 'block gun'. It lets you pick up and drop little blocks. The game changed, mostly, from a mind bender to a mess-with-blocks game. This was a lot less interesting to me personally. Especially since there are various upgrades to the guns which make some puzzles easier (WAY WAY easier in some cases). It was more interesting trying to get through puzzles I knew I was supposed to do later well before I was ready. I even solved a few that were obvious 'get to know your new upgrade' levels before I got those upgrades, just through sheer determination and dinking around with single floating boxes (gets you around a few places, but so hard to do right). Others just thwarted me for a long time (looking at you, darned WTF floorless chamber) and when you get the right upgrade (able to fill in spaces in this case), it's obvious what to do. In any case, though not as strong as the beginning, this was still fun.  Still, all in all, I would give this game an 8/10 for the complete experience and I definitely recommend it for any other puzzle lovers.

Most deeply facinating and well made puzzle game I have ever played.  The real beauty of the puzzles in Antichamber is it's hard to even understand there's a puzzle here, let alone what to do about it. It's more like exploring your brain in a dream than a straight up and down puzzle game. While it does have lots of moments that are more mechanical, mostly it's about changing the very way your mind is perceiving this problem. Often it wasn't a problem at all. The problem was in your brain, not the game.  It's like being trapped in a dream. It's amazing. I'm making it sound like there's no logic to it, that everything is random. But the masterpiece of it is when you realise that all the crazy stuff going on that makes zero sense, and surely can't be happening, suddenly does make sense. The entire game is like that. It challenges the very way your brain works.  The developers must be the kind of people that can solve an entire room of rubix cubes just by squinting their eyes at them for a second.

This game is amazing. Depending on how you approach each problem, you will be countered with such a mind boggling puzzle, which will have you coming back to solve it. My review: 8/10 for sarcasm. 9/10 for puzzles. 8.5/10 for creativity. 9/10 for logic empowerment.

This isn't your conventional puzzle game.   This game really makes you think beyond the boundaries of a video game. There were times when I just sat and thought of the most absurd ways to solve the puzzles; ways which would not be possible in most other puzzle games, and I found this the best way to go about playing this game. Just clear your mind of any preconceived notions about this game and just take it all in.  When you go into this game, it's best you leave behind any knowledge or experience you've had with other puzzle games because this is really going to be a mind****. (Yes, that's a good thing.)  Also, it looks like everything has been made in SketchUp; it's a nice art style and really adds to the tone of the game.

12/10 TLDR: If you enjoy solving the unsolvable, this game should  definitely  be in your colleciton!  This is not a  simple  game.    If you get stuck playing tic-tac-toe, it may not be for you.   If you frustrate easily, it may not be for you.   If you are expecting 30 minutes and done, it's  definitely  not for you.  With that said, if you wish to be challenged in some new and different ways, this game's worth every penny.  Before you play though, I'd make a few suggestions:  Take everything you  think  you know about puzzle games and  throw it out the window.    Don't look up the solutions - if you find yourself stuck or unsure where to go next, walk away (in game or otherwise) and come back later. Sometimes you'll notice things (or places) you didn't before.   No matter how absurd or irrelevant something might seem, don't be afraid to try it - no death/no foul   Sometimes it helps to   take a suggestion straight out of Hansel and Gretel   to see how your world truly is   Do not be disuaded by the 'simplistic' graphics on this game - it has just what it needs. The basic views with color in just the right places actually add to the atmosphere and let you concentrate on the best part ~ the puzzles!  (There is actually some very cleverly integrated 'helpful hints' that also apply to real world advice)  It's a puzzling masterpiece and unlike anything else you've ever played. I guarantee it.

Antichamber is a wonderful exploration of the first-person perspective; it is both about understanding the conventions of FP, and about how those conventions aren't immutable, but are as the parallel lines axiom is to Geometry.  The minimal aesthetic helps immensely to underscore the focus on the puzzle design and mechanics; art direction is clear and consistent.  Soundtrack is a very soothing set of ambient pieces that would not be out of place on Hearts of Space.  In other words, it's right up my alley.

I knew this game was going to play mindgames on me and it still succeeded doing so.  It's an amazing puzzle game that somehow places itself in your subconsciousness so deep that if you get stuck somewhere you'll probably be waking up the next day with the solution to the puzzle striking you as the first thought of that day. And trust me, it's the right solution as well. The design is minimalistic and stunning at the same time.

You round a corner and come to a pair of staircases. On the left is a red staircase going down and on the right is a blue staircase going up. You decide to take the red staircase on the left going down. You head through a corridor and round a few corners to find a pair of staircases. On the left is a red staircase going down and on the right is a blue staircase going up. This time you decide to take the blue staircase on the right going up. You head through a corridor and round a few corners to find a pair of staircases. Around and around you go and you can't seem to find anything but these two staircases. With resignation, you surrender to the puzzle, turn around, and try to head back. You round the corner and find yourself in a corridor you have never seen before.  'Antichamber' is a zen puzzle game. It may mess with your head. A lot. However, it is remarkably relaxed about messing with your head.   There is no one right way to play. If you try, then you succeed. You may hit a dead end, but that is an acceptable result. You are even rewarded for hitting the dead end with some words of encouragement. Then you can just go back and try something different. No worries. There is absolutely no pressure to complete puzzles in time. You are free to take everything at your own pace.   This is quite possibly the most peaceful and pleasant mindscrew a person can experience.

Very engaging and puzzling game with very unique looking visuals. I can't really think of anything negative to say; however if you are not sure if this game is for you, then it would be great to try to get this game on a steam sale, rather than spending money on something that doesn't appeal to your personal tastes. The game can seem to come to dead-ends at points, and leave you with no idea of how to proceed. In such situations, there are some great walkthrough guides for a last-resort solution.  Hopefully, if you were to buy the game, you wouldn't have to resort to that a lot, otherwise it's not a great investment, and of course, would not bring the full enjoyment of this great game.

In front of you is a hallway. You'll want walk slowly at one point, because at a certain point the hallway will transform into a room you've probably been to before if you don't jump, and that area in itself has a confusing layout, with invisible floors, rooms that only allow access if you aren't looking at them as you enter, and areas that only exist if you enter them from the right doorway, not to mention many, many odd block puzzles.  Antichamber probably gets a lot of comparisons to Portal, and for good reason. Both are puzzle games who rely on novel elements of level design and the ability to manipulate the environment to create what could be seen as a larger puzzle as a whole.  However, Antichamber, focuses entirely on the latter. There is no antagonist, no threat of danger. The worst thing that may happen is you accidently boxing yourself in somewhere, and even that is an incredibly minor inconvenience due to your ability to return to any room you have visited from the main menu, which seconds as a sort of universal hub room.  Also unique to this game is its sense of exploration. Antichamber is the best example I can think of as a puzzle-focused first-person Metroidvania-style game, where your only limitation in exploration are which tools you have collected. Oftentimes you will find yourself delightfully lost, as you rush forward only to find yourself back where you began. Antichamber is not about completing the labyrinth, it's about exploring it. Also, there's no David Bowie, pretty fantasy settings, or quirky puppets. But the ability to manipulate reality is a nice consolation prize.

Not sure what the hubbub is about. For all the hyperbole about 'OOOH IT'S SO MINDBENDING', Antichamber is actually pretty straightforward, and quite frankly, dull.   Early on, the game has nothing to offer but a handful of obvious tricks, which you'll see through immediately. At one point the game recreates the Lost Woods from Ocarina of Time (NON-EUCLIDEAN GEOMETRY GUYZ). I'm not sure why a puzzle game with absolutely no consistency is a good idea, because it ultimately boils down to futzing around until something new happens. I was expecting some kind of puzzle game where the laws of physics/reality are altered in some way, but Antichamber is really a set of disjointed illusions for the first hour, until you get the BLOCK GUN.  Upon finding the block gun, the 'mindbending' aspects of the game vanish entirely and lead to an endless series of boring block puzzles. There's really nothing particularly clever, challenging, or interesting going on here. Some of the early block puzzles are alright, but it quickly gets out of hand. One 'puzzle' literally has you soaking up zillions of blocks to build a giant staircase like some boring version of minecraft. It's just tedium.  Most of this is just mediocre, but Antichamber really becomes offensive when all the frustrating parts become apparent. The dangers of having a game centered on changing the rules and warping reality jump out at you when you realize you're missing crucial information. Here we have a game that challenges you to 'accomplish the impossible', and ironically it's impossible to tell what IS possible. You'll spend 10 minutes on one puzzle only to discover that some puzzles are literally unsolvable without some new gadget. I get that the game is meant to be exploratory and somewhat confusing, but some things are explained upfront, and other things are never made clear.  There's very little consistency to the puzzle design. When a game's design depends on unintuitive logic, the challenge usually comes from discovery: observing cause-and-effect relationships so that you can extrapolate the mechanics. Antichamber fails because the puzzles are solved upon the first observation, and since there's no consistent puzzle design, the player just stumbles along without having learned anything. Unfortunately, the lack of direction is compounded by the winding and open-ended nature of the level design. There's really no obvious path to follow, so you spend a lot of time hitting dead-ends, never knowing whether you're missing something, too thick to figure out the solution, or need some new ability.  And the levels branch a LOT as you move along, especially early on when you're exploring everything for the first time. Things tend to close off behind you, so after you pass by a dozen points-of-interest/corridors, your mental 'come-back-to-this' list is overloaded. It doesn't help that Antichamber is visually quite bland. Yes, the screenshots on the store page make it look very cool, as if the game were built in Matlab, but 90% of it consists of blank, white, square corridors. Rare splashes of color don't add much and don't distinguish different areas. Every door is identical. Wandering around and backtracking become doubly irritating when the 'map' is inconsistent, sometimes showing you places you should explore, but not always. Thus you'll spend a lot of time aimlessly wandering around trying to figure out where to go next.  The irritations don't stop there. Traveling around almost always requires you to re-solve the same annoying puzzles again and again, many of which use the equally annoying block gun. Even worse, Antichamber has an irritating habit of warping you to some other part of the game without warning, often forcing you to teleport again to an earlier area and re-solve the same boring puzzles once more. Again, I get that the game is supposed to be confusing, but there comes a point where it's no longer for the sake of challenge.  On top of it all, there's really no ultimate goal or progression. There's no plot or any real sense of place. For a standard puzzle game, I normally wouldn't complain, but Antichamber is definitely reaching for something more. There's some real effort put into the sound design. The ambiance mostly involves odd nature soundscapes; sometimes it works but generally feels out-of-place for a game that is otherwise totally abstract. The game also loves to bask in its own stupidity with truly awful morsels of wisdom it feeds you constantly. In many ways, Antichamber feels like it's aiming for Portal a bit too much, including some blatant puzzle mechanics lifted directly.  In the end, I really can't recommend Antichamber. I think some folks are too easily impressed by a few, admittedly unusual, cheap tricks. Just play Portal. Or The Stanley Parable. Or Echochrome. Or anything else, really.

It's not a puzzle game when clicking sporadically gets you the solution to every puzzle. There's a difference between trial and error to learn some fundamental mechanic and brute forcing your way through every solution. There's no build up of knowledge. In a good puzzle game, you'll find the solution and then think, 'Oh, well that was easy... Why didn't I think of that.' In this game, there's no aha moment. When you solve a puzzle here, you think 'How on earth were you supposed to figure that out given the provided stimuli? That was just stupid.'  The other issue is that there's no sensation of progress or achievement. You end up in the same place 90% of the time and have to go through hoops again to get back to where you wanted to go. It's certainly an approach to doing things non-linearly, but it's a bad approach.

Everyone rants about this game, and I decided to give it a go. At the time of this review, I'm very near the end (I think).  Unfortunately, Antichamber failed to impress me. The environment looks unfinished, the philosophical hindsight wall panels are boringly cliche and the game has no story and almost zero ambience. The only interesting things about the environment are the 'Three Paths in Sight' museum room (which had some creatures I hoped I might encounter) and that black Macguffin block that's always floating out of sight and whispering.   The audio was just confusing in places. What's with all the sounds of nature? Most of the time, it seems to serve no purpose.   This game is supposed to 'mess with my head', which it did for about two minutes. The non-Euclidean geometry that Antichamber employs would probably have been a lot more effective at messing with me if there was any narrative at all to hook me in. But there isn't, so it isn't very impressive. Once you realize that this is all possible because it's a computer game and can have all the wacky spatial physics that it wants, it sort of takes the fun away. To make up for the lack of plot, I imagined that this game is like a benign version of the movie Cube; where you can't die, and if you just persevere, you will eventually complete it. And there are a lot of cubes.   That being said, Antichamber does have some redeeming features. Being able to try any chamber from the start of the game saves you the endless frustration of having to go back through all the other puzzles should you get stuck or fail a section. The game relies quite a bit on a 'learn as you go' approach, which I appreciate, and the help tools were limited, forcing the player to work out the 'Cube Gun' and the different color cube functions on their own. Some of the puzzles were actually quite fun to solve.   One of the problems with puzzle games is that they have little replay value. However, you may want to play them as a quick run-through for nostalgia's sake (Portal series). But for that to happen, the game has to provide you with some desire to play it. As I went further and further into Antichamber and realized that there was no story at all, it robbed me of my motivation and turned the game into just something to complete, which is a disappointment. I feel like it could have been more, but it seems more like a beta build than a finished game that sells for twenty dollars. I'm glad I bought it on sale, because if I had bought it full price, I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Likely as not, I'll uninstall Antichamber once I've completed it and not play it again.   Imagine Portal 2 without GLADOS, Wheatley, Cave Johnson, physics gel, Aerial Faith Plates, cake and only six colors. You've just played Antichamber, and I've just saved you twenty dollars.

I feel like I may be alone in saying this, but Antichamber is not a good game.  It nearly had me at first, tricking me into thinking it was too smart for me. But before long I realized that the game was just trolling me. There are no real hints or clues for the majority of puzzles, and the rules the game establishes for one puzzle are immediately abandoned for the next.  In the end most of the puzzles require a kind of clever, brute force, trial and error. There is never a point where it clicks and you go 'aha!' for any of the puzzles. In fact, if you feel an 'aha!' moment, the game has probably just tricked you into over thinking it. That is the exact opposite of what I want in a surealist puzzle game.

The puzzles in Antichamber aren't difficult; they're tedious and stupid. The answer is usually either apparent right away or very strongly hinted at, but often takes dozens of tries to get to work. Most of the puzzles involve jumps that have to be done at the right split second, chain reactions that may or may not actually work, and clicking the left mouse button over and over again to replace blocks after said botched jumps and chain reactions.  If you want a fun but difficult puzzle experience, try Portal or Myst. Don't play this game unless you got it with the newest Humble Bundle AND enjoy having Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.

Allow me to present my opinion of this game in the form of an argument with a five-year-old:  Me: Okay, so, hi, Antichamber, what do you have for me today? Antichamber: Puzzles! Me: Nice, that's what I was looking for. So what's this first one? AC: Staircases! Me: Okay, I see that. Let's see what happens if I go up this staircase...Surprise, I'm back where I started, interesting. It looks like the same thing happens if I go down. So what do I do now, Antichamber? AC: Look! I made a sign for you! It has stick figures on it! Me: Thanks, that should help, then. Let's see, 'The choice doesn't matter if the outcome is the same?' Thanks, Antichamber, that's pretty obvious already. AC: Hahahaha! I tricked you. Me: Great, well, I'm going backwards, aaaand, hey I'm somewhere else. AC: I knew you were going to do that! Me: So I gathered. How clever of you.  --A couple of minutes later--  Me: Hey, it looks like this is a dead end. Antichamber, what am I- Whoa, the floor disappeared on me. That would be a surprise if you hadn't done that in the previous room. AC: Hahahaha! I tricked you! I'm so smart. Me: Well, since I'm down here, I might as well read this sign. Let's see, 'Life has a way of pushing us in the right direction?' Fascinating. Did you come up with that all by yourself? AC: Yesss! I'm so smart! Me: Cute.  --Later still--  AC: I got you a little gun thingy that shoots blocks where you want them! Me: Ooooh, a new mechanic, nice. Let's try this out. AC: See, you can use it to close switches and hold doors open! Me: That would make sense. Okay, so I guess I go through these beams to open these doors? Okay, seems pretty strightforward. What do I need to do in this next room? It looks like there are ten switches I need to close here. AC: Ha! You don't have enough blocks! You need to go back and get more. See! I tricked you! Me: And the door closed behind me so I can't go back.  AC: Haha, you're stuck in here! Me: So what do I do then, Antichamber? AC: Restart the game! Me: Wait, what? Oh, I can go back to any area I've gone to on the map. Hey, Antichamber, this map doesn't make any sense, nothing lines up. AC: That's because they don't have to! Me: Then it doesn't seem to be a map. Oh, at least the map shows me where I'm going if I look at it. Okay, I'll go back to pick up some more blocks- Wait, I don't have any so I can't go anywhere. Antichamber, where are all the blocks? AC: You need to start from the right place so you have enough blocks! Me: So why let me start here? AC: Uhhhhh....I tricked you! Me: Great.  --A short while later--  Me: It looks like I'm stuck again, Antichamber, I think I'll reset. AC: Okay! Hey, look your timer ran out! Me: Timer? What? Oh, you mean the thing that says 'Live life by your own watch' above it? Why put it there then? AC: Because it's smart! It makes you smarter! Me: Thanks, Antichamber, I figured that out a long time ago.  Ten minutes later I left my job working in a day care for 'indie' games.   Antichamber likes to think it's smart, and, at the beginning, it is, the puzzles are actually pretty clever. However, as the game continues, the fact that it likes to throw something completely unrelated to the previous puzzles at you while smugly preaching at you via meaningless and pretentious 'life lessons' on signs, it starts to grate, and badly. Antichamber doesn't have any ground rules, it can throw whatever it wants at you, and rather than being interesting, it just becomes annoying because of just how badly the game conveys progression; every puzzle starts the same and they eventually merge into a seamless blob of white hallways where none of the choices you make affect your environment. As I illustrated above, it is the game equivalent of arguing with a small child, one who thinks he's smarter than you. Games are supposed to have rules, of what you can and cannot do, and what the game can and cannot do. Antichamber, on the other hand, can do whatever it wants, while your rules stay the same. In a debate, this is known as 'moving the goalposts' and it is an extremely cheap method of getting your opponent to keep arguing, and in a game it is a cheap and annoying tactic of trying to keep the game feeling fresh.  This is not a game intended for people who liked Portal. Portal had rules of what both you and the game can and cannot do with portals, while Antichamber does whatever it wants and laughts because you were foolish enough to assume that it would follow some kind of 'thread.'

This game literally broke my soul. It continuously beats you over the head saying, 'LEARN LEARN LEARN' without giving you any indication of what the solution is. I wanted to enjoy it based on the portal series but instead I just want to delete this crappy excuse for a game and never play it again.

While this game is an amazing and fun puzzle game it falls short in one aspect: the wild changing of colors is enough to make you nauseous in a very short period of time. If you can stand rapid color change and disorientation, this is a great game, however I can not and after 15 minutes I need a lie down.

Maybe I'm just bad, but when I spent a couple of hours trying to find the second gun I gave up. The pompous writing on the wall, the 'lazy' artstyle all became increasingly frustrating as I realized that I'd ran through the same area 3 times. You might not hate this game, but I really couldn't get into it. It's the only game I've ever thought of as a pretentious hipster art game.
Nauseating experience. Every time I played this game, I felt sick for hours afterwards. Never happened to me before with any other game.
